results.title: Leonardo. The Divine Michelangelo
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, Discovery Channel and Leslie Megahey
results.brief_description: Two fascinating documentary television series about the most influential artists of the Italian Renaissance. The first disc contains three parts to the television series about Leonard da Vinci and his work/creations. Written and presented by Alan Yentob. Presented as docu-drama with actors playing the roles of Leonardo and his contemporaries in a costume-drama style setting, with mock interviews and commentaries to make what would otherwise be straightforward information be imparted in a most enlightening and educative/entertaining way. The second disc contains two parts to the television series about Michelangelo. Narrated by Susannah York. “Program One” is about his triumph of the statue of David and “Program Two” is about the painting of the Sistine Chapel and his architectural designs.

results.title: Leonard French's stained glass screens [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Michael Thornhill
results.brief_description: The National Library in Canberra is the repository of some of the most distinguished works of art in Australia. Among them is a set of twelve stained glass screens executed by painter Leonard French. Taking as his theme the planets, French designed a set of screens which drew on the craggy beauty of medieval stained glass for their inspiration. In Italian language.

results.title: Leon Morin, Pretre = Leon Morin, Priest
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard, Carlo Ponti and Jean-Pierre Melville
results.brief_description:
Aiming successfully for a wider audience in 1961, the neglected French independent Jean-Pierre Melville (‘Les enfants terribles’, ‘Le samourai’) adapted Beatrix Beck’s autobiographical novel, set in a French village during World War II, about a young woman falling in love with a handsome, radical young priest who is fully aware of his power over her. For the starring roles Melville, godfather of the New Wave, ironically selected two talented actors catapulted to fame by that movement— Emmanuelle Riva (‘Hiroshima mon amour’) and Jean-Paul Belmondo (‘Breathless’). The poetic results are literary and personal; the heroine’s offscreen narration suggests the pre-Bressonian form of Melville’s first feature, ‘Le silence de la mer’, and sudden subjective shots convey the woman’s physical proximity to the priest as she undergoes an ambiguous religious conversion. Not an unqualified success, the film remains strong for its performances, its inventive editing and framing, and its evocative rendering of the French Occupation. According to Melville, the film ran for 193 minutes in its pre-release form; he edited out 65 minutes, and another 18 minutes are missing from the present version. The eclectic and resourceful non jazz score is by jazz pianist Martial Solal. Reference: Jonathan Rosenbaum, Chicago Reader. Online. http://onfilm.chireader.com Awards: Grand Prix de la Ville de Venise, 1961.

Credits: Producers, Georges de Beauregard, Carlo Ponti ; director, Jean-Pierre Melville ; writer, Jean-Pierre Melville ; photography, Henri Decae, Jean Rabier ; music, Martial Solal ; assistant director, Volker Schlondorff.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Emmanuelle Riva, Howard Vernon.

results.title: Leo Beuerman
results.brief_description: Documents the life of Leo Beuerman, an unusual man, physically handicapped since birth, describing his ability to overcome diversity and his philosophy of life. Tells how Leo was able to see a path through his handicap and arrive at a point where he is able to enjoy life. Background music sets a moody and relaxed feel to this unusual and interesting film. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
